content:
There are many good websites available to learn java.

following are few of my suggestions based on your learning style:

  • Learn by Reading Web content
    1. JavaTpoint: Javatpoint - A Solution of all Technology
    2. StudyTonight: Best place to learn
    3. Tutorialspoints: tutorialspoints.com
  • Learn by watching video
    1. NPTEL: DSL
    2. Lynda: Lynda: Online Courses, Classes, Training, Tutorials
    3. NewBoston: http://newboston.com
    4. durgasoft Youtube channel: Durga Software Solutions
  • Learn through practice and competing in programming
    1. HackerRank
    2. HackerEarth - Programming challenges and Developer jobs
    3. CodeFights
    4. Programming Competition,Programming Contest,Online Computer Programming

For more help get help from google or go through community curated resources.

All The Best!

Happy Learning!

O(n): buying items from a grocery list by proceeding down the list one item at a time, where “n” is the length of the list

O(n): buying items from a grocery list by walking down every aisle (now “n” is the length of the store), if we assume list-checking time is trivial compared to walking time

O(n): adding two numbers in decimal representation, where n is the number of digits in the number.

O(n^2): trying to find two puzzle pieces that fit together by trying all pairs of pieces exhaustively

O(n^2): shaking hands with everybody in the room; but this is parallelized, so each person only does O(n) work.

O(n^2): multiplying two numbers using the grade-school multiplication algorithm, where n is the number of digits.

O( log n ): work done by each participant in a phone tree that reaches N people. Total work is obviously O( n ), though.

O( log n ): finding where you left off in a book that your bookmark fell out of, by successively narrowing down the range

I am going to share 5 to 6 programming laguage that will definitely going to help you, before that you should learn some basic coding for better development.

  • ASP.NET Development: ASP.NET is an open source web framework, created by Microsoft, for building modern web apps and services that run on macOS, Linux, Windows, and Docker.
  • React JS Development: React components implement a render() method that takes input data and returns what to display.
  • Vue JS Development: Vue.js is an open-source model–view–viewmodel front end JavaScript framework for building user interfaces and single-page applications.
  • Angular Development: Angular is a TypeScript-based free and open-source web application framework led by the Angular Team at Google and by a community of individuals and corporations.
  • Blazor Development: Blazor is a feature of ASP.NET for building interactive web UIs using C# instead of JavaScript.
  • Python Development: Python is a high-level, general-purpose programming language. Its design philosophy emphasizes code readability with the use of significant indentation.

You can contact with any software development company, that will also help you. One of the most trustworthy and experienced web development company in USA. Their team makes sure all the components of a project, from front-end to back-end is delivered exactly as per the business requirements

First of all, keep in mind that NoSQL isn’t a language or a product. There are over 220 products that call themselves NoSQL, and they each have different uses.

Whereas SQL is a language, but not a specific implementation of that language. Talking about the “performance of SQL” doesn’t make sense, because SQL is a language specification. Just a document that describes the language, not a software product. There are many implementations of SQL, and they each have strengths for different types of queries.

Then you have to ask: Faster for what? Data updates? Inserts? Single-row queries? Complex queries? The question as stated is practically meaningless. Depending on what you're doing, any technology might be optimal.

In short: No, NoSQL is not faster than SQL, nor is SQL faster than NoSQL. They are each different technologies suited to different work.

Questions like yours are common, but naively assume there is one right answer. We might as well ask a carpenter if a hammer is better than a drill or a saw. They are all tools, useful for the purposes for which they were designed. It makes no sense to use one or the other exclusively.

Yes.

The current Java logo. “Java” refers to coffee, not the tropical island. The letters in the name don’t stand for anything, unlike BASIC and ForTran do (image credit)

Java was carefully designed by professional and highly regarded software language architects. The primary goal was “write once, run anywhere”, but the designers had several other design goals as well. Such as:

  • Easy to use
  • Object-oriented

And others. Based on C and C++ in terms of syntax, Java sported a familiar syntax, but was easier to use and more consistent than the other primary OO language of that time, C++. And thanks to the Java Virtual Machine, it was truly “write once, run anywhere”.

One version of a JavaScript logo (image credit) (https://www.seekpng.com/ipng/u2q8t4a9y3w7t4i1_javascript-logo-logo-de-java-script-png/)

JavaScript, on the other hand, was designed in 10 days by a software engineer who was more less blindsided by the order to develop a new language that ran in the browser. Based on Java syntax and other languages, JavaScript first appeared in Netscape Navigator as a “scripting language” for Java applets that could run in the browser.

It is not OO and wasn’t really meant to be a full language; it was just meant to drive Java applets and provide a little extra functionality. It’s role has grown exponentially since 1995, when it was launched. It’s still not OO (though it does use “objects”, it uses them in a perverse, awkward manner). Its strengths are “functional programming”, which means writing functions that don’t have any side-effects.

In short, Java was carefully designed and is a stable, reliable OO language. JavaScript was developed in a hurry and it shows. Both languages have been upgraded over the years. While Java has deprecated features that were deemed unreliable, JavaScript has embraced its defects and extended them. Both are better than they were when they were first launched, but there’s little in common between them.

I suggest figuring out the program from the top down. That's usually the best way to think about recursion.

Let's start by working out what the two functions do. First, the function DoMerge takes an array of numbers that's split into two consecutive intervals. Each of the intervals is assumed to be already sorted, and the numbers are interleaved so that they end up as a single sorted sequence. Okay, but you said you did not have much trouble with that part.

Now let's find out what MergeSort_Recursive(int [] numbers, int left, int right) is supposed to do. It is given an array of numbers, and two numbers "left" and "right" that are presumably the beginning and end of an interval in the array that should be sorted.

Now there are two ways to think about recursion. The first is to follow the program's execution deeper and deeper into the recursion, but that can get confusing and is only really useful if you want to understand how recursion works. It does not help you design a recursive procedure.

So we'll start with the other way of thinking, which is to do a suspension of disbelief. Simply believe that MergeSort_Recursive already works as it's supposed to. If that is the case, then we can simply read recursive function calls as "sort that subarray please (using some code that I'm assuming somehow works)".

Now the function becomes very easy to read: it splits the array that has to be sorted in two, it sorts the left half (don't worry about it, just accept it), then it sorts the right half (again, don't worry about it), and then it merges the two sorted blocks together. If you read it that way, it looks pretty simple doesn't it?

But what kind of magic makes it all work? Well, the trick is that the calls to Mergesort_Recursive request sorting a smaller array than we started out with each time. So when the computer starts executing the routine recursively, it splits that smaller array in two halves again, and makes two further recursive calls. And this way it goes on a couple of levels deep, until at some point, we arrive at an array of only a single item! In that case, we will have right<=left, and the function will not do anything, so the recursion stops.

Let there be N nodes.

Then the height of a Binary Search Tree ranges from N-1 to log(N).

therefore in the given question the height will range from 31 to log(32)= 5.
